Senior/Staff Engineer
Senior/Staff Backend Software Engineer (Rust
Come help us build the best API testing tool
Who are we?
ForAllSecure is a group of people united by a shared mission: making the world’s software safe & reliable. Our first step towards that goal is to democratize fuzzing.

Fuzzing is an automated testing technique with huge impact. Microsoft reports that 80%+ of their security vulnerabilities are discovered by fuzzing. But only the biggest tech companies and best vulnerability researchers have had the resources to leverage fuzzing. We are here to break down these barriers and bring fuzzing to the masses.
Continuous fuzzing will transform how we test software in our industry at large. It will be as fundamental as unit or integration testing
column2: and we are responsible for making that positive change happen. It will empower developers to build better and safer software

column1: What will you do?
You will join a small team passionate about API testing. We believe that there is a better way to develop and test web APIs
column2: and that fuzzing is part of the solution. We are driven to deliver that and help out all the API developers out there.

column1: We are looking for people with the same passion to help build this nascent product. Your day to day will likely involve
Adding features to our CLI and web API that will unlock more value for our customers.
Working with our customers to understand how we can better provide a valuable & delightful experience.
Coming up with feature ideas
column2: and owning them from start to finish (ideation

column1: Optionally
You don’t know fuzzing
column2: or much about security? That’s alright! We’d love to teach you. And there’s plenty of work around the fuzzing tech (CLI/API) if that’s something you’re more comfortable.

column1: Oh

column1: Who are we looking for?
We do not care about your credentials

column2: and you are excited to drive it forward.

column1: Empathy. You care deeply about your co-workers and your customers. You will make technical decisions affecting our users
column2: and we want users to always be on top of mind.

column1: Curiosity. You love to learn. You love to get better at things
column2: through reading books or blog posts. You consider yourself a fast learner.

column1: Writing skills. You appreciate and are inspired by well-written documentation. You like writing your thoughts down and sharing them with others.
Coding skills. We do not require formal education

column3: background jobs). Specific frameworks and tools are less important.

column1: Our Team Culture
Culture is very important to our team
column2: and therefore wanted to share with you what you can expect if you were to join us:

column1: Small & lean team. Highly motivated & lean team. You’ll be the 3rd engineer on the product.
Remote-first. We have folks on both US coasts
Speed: Eric Ries claims speed at which you iterate is key. Iteration is not only about software
column2: but about ""validated learnings"". He advocates a scientific approach to product development
column3: built around quick validation of hypotheses using data from customers. This involves things like Reid Hoffman’s paper testing

column1: Data-driven decision making: Iteration speed enables data-driven decision making. Instead of arguing about what to build
column2: we look at the date collected from customers. Many times
column3: the decision requires more data and the discussion shifts to how we can get it.

column1: Empowerment: Another important aspect of our decision making is that our team is empowered to make decisions. This avoids a number of issues. First
column2: given that we are on the ground and close to customers (see ""Empathy"" below)
column3: we have the most context on how we can provide value to them
column4: which is how we make this product successful. Second
column6: giving team decision-making authority allows them to remain nimble & fast
column7: there's not a lengthy approval process for inconsequential decisions.

column1: Focus: The result of iteration speed & data-driven decision making is focus. We might not always build stuff that customers want (mistakes happen
column2: and that's ok - see below). But the important part is we only keep what customers want. We don't want any dead weight slowing us down.

column1: Psychological safety: iteration speed reduces the impact of mistakes. We avoid investing too much effort without regular validation of the work. So
column4: and failure is just another ""validated learning"". This gives the team psychological safety
column5: one of the 5 elements of high performing teams. On the technical side
column6: continuous delivery also dampens any mistakes we make. While a mistake may find its way to production faster
column7: it also gets fixed in production faster.

column1: Empathy: Engineers are close to customers. We get unfiltered feedback right from customers instead of playing a game of telephone. We can ask clarification questions. We can test our hypothesis. This also gives us the context and empathy we need in order to make good decisions. The product would not be successful if we did not do that. The empathy we gain from talking directly to customers also leads us to put a huge focus on usability

Async communications: Another aspect of our decision making is that we embrace written communications over meetings. It enables the writer to be more deliberate with their thinking. They have the time to do research and build a coherent and backed case. It gives people a shared background to start an informed discussion. More specifically
column2: we follow an RFD process for important technical decisions.

column1: Work-life balance. We care to have well-balanced & diverse team members. We can’t have that if we expect folks to work crazy hours. Heads up
column2: you will however be expected to be part of an on-call rotation.";;;

Job Summary

The laboratory of Professor Aaron Quinlan (quinlanlab.org) at the University of Utah’s Department of Human Genetics and Biomedical Informatics is seeking an experienced C++ or Rust software developer to lead the development of new algorithms and software for genomics research. The candidate will contribute to the development and application of computational methods to multiple ongoing studies of rare human disorders and cancer genome analysis. The ideal candidate will have obtained their Bachelor degree and have: a background in molecular biology
column3: experience exploring modern DNA sequencing datasets
column4: and expertise in both with C++ or Rust. Applicants should have a passion for solving complex problems and value collaboration and teamwork while also being able to work individually. The candidate will be expected to play a role in collaborating with other groups at the University of Utah and other institutions; participate interact with scientists within the group; publish their work in peer-reviewed journals; and present their work in national and international meetings. A high degree of organization and professionalism is required. We offer a competitive salary and benefits package for highly qualified candidates.

column1: The successful candidate will join a vibrant and collaborative community of computational

column3: Utah lies at the interface between basic and clinical sciences
column4: creating ample opportunities for collaborations with clinical researchers and easy access to high-valued clinical datasets. The institution is set on the Wasatch front in Salt Lake City and provides a unique recreational and geographical landscape that attracts a very diverse and productive scientific community.

The Quantum team's mission is to make useful quantum computing tools available to the world to enable humankind to solve problems that would otherwise be impossible. Quantum AI is building novel systems that can leverage quantum mechanics to outperform the world's largest computers at certain classes of problems.
Quantum computers rely on quantum mechanics

column6: performant software to calibrate and control quantum devices. You will work on scaling our calibration systems to manage larger quantum devices with more qubits
column7: as well as a larger number of devices in our growing fleet.

column1: Job Description

We are looking for an enthusiastic software engineer that is familiar with embedded firmware development. The role is to develop firmware that will power Western Digital’s next-generation security platform. You will contribute at all levels of the firmware stack from low-level SPI and HID interfaces all the way up to the application business logic.

Design
column3: and write efficient embedded firmware code using Rust and C.

Security/Systems Postdoctoral Scholar;https://www.indeed.com/viewjob?jk=8c5edf36aa9b86a0;San Francisco Bay Area, CA;no;

The Computing Sciences Research Area has an immediate opening for a post-doctoral researcher to perform vital research and development in the area of the use of trusted execution environments (TEEs) in high-performance computing (HPC) domains. The goal of this work is to enable high-performance scientific computing of sensitive data without significantly compromising usability or performance. The work includes software development of and experimentation with security and privacy technologies critical to facilitate data collection and sharing.

The goal of this position is to contribute to developing and implementing new trusted execution environment architectures and related low-level system software appropriate to the threat model and performance requirements of high-performance scientific computing. Our solution involves a RISC-V based architectural development
column2: development of and modifications to low-level operating system elements

column1: Important qualities of the position include experience in low-level operating system elements and experience with software development.
What you will do:
In the context of scientific research and data
column2: the position will be expected to extend the state of the art of trustworthy scientific computing by advancing hardware trusted execution environments (TEEs) for high-performance computing (HPC) in one or more directions. This may include:

column1: Development and analysis of system-level software (e.g.
column3: drivers) that ameliorate the mismatch between existing systems
column4: scientific use cases and threat models

column1: Development or modification of software libraries that address needs for encrypted communication between and within system components in an HPC system with minimal latency.
Write scientific research papers suitable for submission to peer-reviewed computer science venues.
Work closely with researchers and application scientists throughout the DOE Office of Science community
column2: with faculty and students from university partners
column3: with researchers in the Computing Sciences Research Area at the Berkeley Lab
column4: where this position is housed; and with staff at the DOE Office of Science’s NERSC supercomputing facility.

column4: or a related technical field is required.

column1: Proficiency and experience in programming languages including low-level programming languages used in systems software
column3: and higher-level languages used in data analysis

Desired Qualifications:

Familiarity with assembly language and/or the RISC-V Instruction Set Architecture.
For full consideration

column1: About the Department

Cloudflare's Engineering Team builds and runs the software that handles trillions of requests per month. We also build and run the internal tools that build and run our software. The Engineering Team is split into two groups: one handles product development and the other handles operations. Product development covers both new features and functionality and scaling our existing software to meet the challenges of a massively growing customer base. The operations team handles one of the world's largest networks with data centers in 200+ cities worldwide.

column1: What’s in a title?
Here at Two Barrels we don’t take titles very seriously. We know for recruiting purposes we need to call our jobs something
column2: so we started with labeling and differentiating them in a fairly traditional way with “junior
column5: we’ve realized that was putting our employees in a box and wasn’t allowing us to uniquely identify their individual contributions
column6: strengths and professional goals. Once you join our team the titles kinda get dropped as we expect everyone to work with everyone regardless of title or experience. We have taken the approach of evaluating candidates and employees on a “level” basis. It makes it a little easier internally to talk about growing into the next level without there being this huge chasm between what it means to be a Junior Engineer vs. a Mid Engineer. Our levels have expectations set for each one and it’s the responsibility of the manager and employee to make sure there is alignment. We do this through quarterly conversations where we discuss employee progression
column8: and to ensure they feel fairly compensated for their work and expertise. Basically

column1: Low level engineer (C++ / Rust / Go);https://justjoin.it/offers/seekr-low-level-engineer-c-rust-go;Berlin;no;"DescriptionOnline interviewFriendly offerLow level engineer (C++ / Rust / Go) Truly challenging work is actually quite difficult to find. Consider this advert a big green flag. Lots of job adverts talk about “building distributed systems at scale” but do they really have the numbers to back it up? Where a company has been around long enough to have seriously impressive user numbers has the interesting work all been done? Are they too big to innovate? Are they a social media company that wants to farm their users’ data? Are they a start-up that thinks they will have a million users but have no idea how they will actually get there? This business is none of those things they already have 12 million users and their product actually helps people protect their privacy on the internet from the prying eyes of all kinds of digital bad actors (including those working for FAANG.inc). The team at SEEKR is helping them in their mission by finding them awesome software engineers to join a new squad in Berlin (remote roles are also available). Here is what is on offer; Technically challenging work – work on software with millions of users across the globe running on in excess of 5000 servers. If your code breaks thousands of people lose their access to the internet. Resilience is baked into everything you do. Culture of innovation – You will have the chance to spend a fair amount of time in this role wearing an R&D hat and looking at writing software to test new ideas. One of the team leads we spoke to has already registered 3 patents in his time there! Friendly colleagues – This is a global business that feels like a friendly start-up. The teams are small
column2: they care about culture and the lack of big egos means there is plenty of space to create your own niche. What do they need from you? If you don’t code in C/C++ right now you probably did in the past You are fascinated by the internals of various all various operating systems. Your code will form the bedrock for applications teams building for Linux
column5: and iOS. You will likely already have a deep understanding of one of the above and you have written cross-platform code in the past. Go or Rust is on your radar and you are itching to try these languages out in an environment that would truly test their capabilities How do you get involved? Apply to this advert. column1: About the position:

For this role you will be working on the Solang compiler - an LLVM frontend written in Rust that compiles Solidity to WebAssembly. This compiler targets multiple WebAssembly environments. One of them is Substrate’s module for smart contracts. An important part of your work will be to keep up with changes in the Solidity language and Substrate’s smart contracts module.

Expect to deal with LLVM IR and dig deep into Solidity language specifics in order to improve the quality of the generated code. There will be a lot of creative freedom and we expect you to identify and accomplish whatever necessary to provide first class Solidity support for our smart contracts platform.
Feature parity with the official solc compiler
column2: improving performance and possibly inline assembly transpilation are some of the things on our roadmap.

column1: You will be working with Alex (contract module maintainer) and be in regular contact with the ink! team.
Requirements:
Experience with Rust.
Experience with implementing LLVM frontends OR deep experience with Solidity.
Familiarity with the Rust ecosystem.
Nice to have:

For this role you will be mostly maintaining and adding new features to an existing Solidity compiler with a focus on generating WebAssembly code. Deep knowledge in one of the following areas is especially appreciated.
Knowing the ins and outs of the Solidity language.
Deep knowledge of the LLVM project and ability to upstream changes.
Deep knowledge of the Wasm specification and upcoming proposals.
Deep knowledge of the Ethereum virtual machine (EVM).
Benefits:
Competitive salaries and benefits.
Opportunity to become an expert in the latest blockchain technologies.

column1: We realize people do not fit into neat boxes. We are looking for curious and empathetic individuals who are committed to developing themselves and learning new skills

column1: About the Department

Cloudflare’s Engineering Team builds and runs the software that handles trillions of requests per month. We also build and run the internal tools that build and run our software. The Engineering Team is split into two groups: one handles product development and the other handles operations. Product development covers both new features and functionality and scaling our existing software to meet the challenges of a massively growing customer base. The operations team handles one of the world’s largest networks with data centers in 200+ cities worldwide.
What you'll do

The product you will work on will fundamentally change how people interact with the internet. You will be making the internet faster and safer for everyone around the world. You are expected to lead the developer effort for common high performance networking code that runs across five platforms (Windows
column4: Android and Linux). You will work closely with platform-specific app developers who rely on your low-level code to get the job done.

You have a passion for growing yourself and your teammates and always have your sights set on getting better. You strive to have a positive impact and leave a positive impression on everyone you meet. You want to be a part of building something you can be proud of.

We process billions of events per day from hundreds of thousands of systems worldwide. We use Go to build-out our backend processes supporting our telemetry collection sensor platform.We continuously push product enhancements to production

column1: Software Engineer - VoIP (Go/Rust);https://startup.jobs/software-engineer-voip-go-rust-element-3152653;Remote;yes;Who We AreElement is the startup that employs the core team behind matrix.org— the leading project for secure
column2: open decentralised communication.Matrix’s mission is to make messaging as open as email — allowing everyone to choose where their data is hosted
column3: enjoy private conversations thanks to advanced encryption
column4: and ultimately be in control of their own communication.Matrix powers Element
column5: our flagship messaging apps for the web
column8: our SaaS platform for personal & professional use.We build things for everyone
column9: and we know we can’t succeed without a diverse team. Our hiring process is designed to be humane and give candidates the best chance to show us what you can do. If we ever fall down on this
column10: please let us know.The RoleElement is heavily investing in building out Matrix as the missing signalling layer for WebRTC: providing an open and decentralised E2EE transport for negotiating media streams and data channels. On top
column11: we have recently extended Matrix to support scalable decentralised E2EE group voice and video calling too (MSC3401). These are the base building blocks for visionary applications such as Element Call as well as the open metaverse (aka third room). For the sake of scalability and reliability in conferencing
column12: a selective forwarding unit (SFU) has proven to be one of the crucial components. The concept is already part of MSC3401. The VoIP team will be responsible for designing and implementing a Matrix compatible SFU which can be extended to support a generic media connector model. We also aim to connect to more legacy systems
column15: as we are trying to work on interoperability with a unified collaboration & communication vision. Currently Element Call relies on a full-mesh node setup. You’d come along to help evolve the SFU
column16: using a modern stack that ensures future compatibility and an end-to-end responsibility for VoIP conferencing. Our VoIP team ensures that there is a communication layer for an open metaverse
column17: so this is a great chance to make a big impact on the future of communication.Since (almost) everything we do is open source you can get a great feel for exactly what it would be like to work on the team
column18: come and say hi!RequirementsAs part of our VoIP Team you are fascinated by real-time audio and video processing. You enjoy exciting challenges and work scientifically on cutting-edge technologies. You will be responsible for developing audio / video infrastructure components and services. Your ideas and work will improve our real-time communication platform which is used by several million users per day. The most important thing is that you believe passionately in the mission of decentralisation of the internet. More specifically that you believe that communications should not be centralised in the hands of a small number of very large organisations and instead individuals should control their own data and choose who they share it with.Additionally we are looking for someone who is: Smart

column1: Senior/Staff Engineer
Come help us build the best API testing tool
Who are we?
ForAllSecure is a group of people united by a shared mission: making the world’s software safe & reliable. Our first step towards that goal is to democratize fuzzing.

Fuzzing is an automated testing technique with huge impact. Microsoft reports that 80%+ of their security vulnerabilities are discovered by fuzzing. But only the biggest tech companies and best vulnerability researchers have had the resources to leverage fuzzing. We are here to break down these barriers and bring fuzzing to the masses.
Continuous fuzzing will transform how we test software in our industry at large. It will be as fundamental as unit or integration testing
column2: and we are responsible for making that positive change happen. It will empower developers to build better and safer software

column1: What will you do?
You will join a small team passionate about API testing. We believe that there is a better way to develop and test web APIs
column2: and that fuzzing is part of the solution. We are driven to deliver that and help out all the API developers out there.

Async communications: Another aspect of our decision making is that we embrace written communications over meetings. It enables the writer to be more deliberate with their thinking. column5: simplest service mesh for Kubernetes.Linkerd is an open source project. It has a thriving community of adopters and it powers the production systems of companies around the world. Companies like Microsoft
column10: many more use Linkerd to add critical security
column12: and observability features to their Kubernetes applications.We’re a small company with an incredibly outsized impact on the world. We’re remote-first and fully distributed with team members all over the world. Our competition is fierce: every day
column13: we take on some of the largest companies in the world with essentially infinite dollars and infinite engineers to devote to their competing projects. Our secret weapon? Focus
column14: and a deep sense of empathy for our users.Working here is not for the faint of heart.What's Linkerd?Imagine taking ultralight
column16: sticking them next to other people's applications running on other people's clusters
column17: and having them mediate all TCP (and in the future
column18: UDP) communication to and from these apps—no matter what it is. Imagine these proxies upgrading connections from HTTP/1 to HTTP/2
column21: emitting fine-grained metrics
column22: issuing CSRs to the local CA every n hours
column23: and so on. And imagine the end user blissfully operating 10
column26: with an easy-to-use CLI and API. That's a service mesh.(The best way to learn more is to try it yourself. If you can run Kubernetes
column27: you can get Linkerd up and running in 5 minutes.)Under the hood Linkerd is extremely sophisticated and deeply technical
column28: but the key to the entire project is simplicity. It's extremely difficult to make a simple service mesh
column29: and very easy to make a complex one. (Heck
column30: look at pretty much any of the other options.) And simplicity in this case means operational simplicity: it doesn't mean that you get a one-click install wizard
column31: it means that whenever Linkerd is running
column32: you can understand what it's doing and predict its behavior. It means no leaky abstractions
column34: no hidden gotchas. We spend a lot of time and energy in ensuring Linkerd is simple—it's our central promise to our users.Linkerd is a graduated-tier project of the Cloud Native Computing Foundation
column35: just like Kubernetes
column37: and other defining projects of the cloud native space. It's written in Rust and Go; Go powers (most of) Linkerd's control plane. Rust powers Linkerd2-proxy
column38: the source of Linkerd's true power. We're the only service mesh that uses something like Linkerd2-proxy
column39: and it's a tremendous differentiator.On the commercial side
column40: we make Buoyant Cloud
column41: a cloud-based management system for Linkerd. Buoyant Cloud makes Linkerd stress-free to operate. You connect your existing deployments
column42: and Buoyant Cloud monitors their health and alerts you if anything looks weird. It takes on the toil of upgrades
column44: and more. In short: Buoyant Cloud turns Linkerd into a managed service
column45: even though it's running on your own clusters.What are you looking for?In this role
column46: we're looking for people who want to work on Linkerd2-proxy. Linkerd2-proxy is built in Rust on top of frameworks like Hyper
column48: and Tokio. It's not trivial code: Linkerd2-proxy has to be extremely performant
column50: and it has to gracefully handle any network traffic that the application sends to it
column51: no matter what. It has to be capable of scaling up to huge levels of load and handling tens of thousands of concurrent connections
column52: and scaling down to consume the smallest amount of resources in low-traffic situations. And it's not just throughput-sensitive but latency sensitive: every millisecond of additional latency in the proxy means can add 10s of milliseconds of latency to the user's application. And it has to handle all of that gracefully
column55: and while running in a container on unpredictable hardware with an unpredictable network.This is a Rust job
column56: but we are not looking for Rust-only idealogues. We're a small company and everyone wears a lot of hats. You will need to write some Go. You will need to interact with actual users and treat them nicely even if they ask silly questions.Linkerd is an open source project
column57: and it feels like one: we have a lot of users
column58: a continuous stream of GitHub issues and Slack messages asking for help or describing problems or asking when something is going to be ready. The cloud native space is rife with buzz
column60: and distraction. You need to be able to be productive in that environment.We interact with our Linkerd users in the community Slack and we try to engage with them authentically while not being distracted. You don't have to deliver keynotes at Kubecon (unless you want to!)
column61: but participating in the community is part of your job.We’re a team

column1: Why Deliveroo?
When you first think about Deliveroo
column2: you probably think of getting great food to your house in less than half an hour. Awesome right? But behind the scenes is the real story. This story is one of high growth
column4: and an enormous opportunity ahead of us. It began with our founder Will
column5: arriving in London in 2004 and finding it almost impossible to order great food
column6: despite the wealth of incredible restaurants in the city. In 2013 Deliveroo was launched. Fast forward to 2020 and we operate in 12 markets with over 60

column1: We want to be the definitive food company - the app you go to any time you have a hunger pang. We are transforming the way people think about food. We are providing people with limitless access to different cuisines and restaurants
column2: turning cooking from a chore to a choice
column3: and giving people the freedom to eat what they want when they want

column1: We work with riders
column3: and consumers. We operate one of the most complex three sided marketplaces in the world and we do this in real-time. Millions of customers and thousands of restaurants and riders rely on us to match them within milliseconds. The algorithms behind that marketplace are the secret sauce that allows us to deliver our orders in around 30 minutes.

column1: And we're just getting started.

The scale of the opportunity ahead of us is immense. The global food market is valued at £7.7 trillion but only 1% of it is currently online. Contrast that with the digital disruption of countless other industries - from banking and travel to retail and communications - it's clear that our journey in the food sector has only just begun.
We are already a multi-billion pound company that has grown rapidly. Deliveroo came top in the FT's' list of Europe's fastest-growing 1000 companies in 2018
column2: and we were the first company ever to win Deloitte's 'UK Top 50' two years in a row. Yet most of the extraordinary value this company will generate lies ahead of us.

column1: Benefits and Diversity
At Deliveroo we know that people are the heart of the business and we prioritise their welfare. We offer a wide range of competitive benefits in areas including health

We believe a great workplace is one that represents the world we live in and how beautifully diverse it can be. That means we have no judgment when it comes to any one of the things that make you who you are - your gender
column5: or a secret aversion to coriander. All you need is a passion for (most) food and a desire to be part of one of the fastest-growing startups in an incredibly exciting space.";;;
